definition: To change something so it works well in new conditions; to adjust.
examples: Animals adapt to the seasons.
We adapted the plan after the survey.

extra.memory_tip: Adapt = add aptness for a new situation.

definition: To use up the supply of something.
examples: Long droughts deplete reservoirs.
Late-night study depleted my energy.

definition: Working well without wasting time, effort, or resources.
examples: LED bulbs are efficient and long-lasting.
She runs an efficient classroom.

definition: Great tiredness; to make very tired.
examples: After the marathon, fatigue hit everyone. (noun)
Heat can fatigue metal over time. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Fatigue = you feel ‘beat’ from head to feet.

definition: A person’s or animal’s way of walking or running.
examples: Her quick gait matched her mood.
Horses have different gaits like trot and canter.

extra.memory_tip: Gait = how your legs ‘gate’ you forward.

definition: A very bright, harsh light; to shine blindingly or to stare angrily.
examples: Close the curtains to cut the glare. (noun)
He glared at the noisy crowd. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Glare = gl-are: light or look that’s hard to bear.

definition: The natural home or environment of a plant or animal.
examples: Wetlands are a habitat for many birds.
Protecting habitat helps endangered species.

definition: Not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around you.
examples: He walked on, oblivious to the rain.
She was oblivious to the whispers.

extra.memory_tip: Oblivious = obvious things can be invisible to you.

definition: No longer fashionable or useful; old-fashioned.
examples: They replaced outmoded equipment.
That view is outmoded today.

definition: Important and well-known; standing out so as to be easily seen.
examples: She is a prominent scientist.
The castle stands in a prominent position.

extra.memory_tip: Prominent = projects out from the rest.

definition: To satisfy thirst; to put out a fire or light.
examples: Water will quench your thirst.
Firefighters quenched the blaze.

extra.memory_tip: Quench = quick end to thirst or flames.

definition: Great strictness, accuracy, or difficulty; harsh and demanding conditions.
examples: The experiment was designed with rigour.
They survived the rigours of winter.

extra.memory_tip: Rigour = rigid care in doing things right.

definition: To burn or char the surface of something; to cause sudden, intense pain.
examples: Sear the steak for a minute on each side.
Hot sand seared his feet.

extra.memory_tip: Sear = sear the surface, seal the juices.

definition: The movement of people or goods; to carry from one place to another.
examples: Public transport reduces traffic. (noun)
Lorries transport goods overnight. (verb)

definition: To go or travel in a slow or indirect way.
examples: We wended our way through the market.
After tea, they wended home at dusk.
